author: @harryaarrestad583

comment: Is it an AGI? It passes the sniff test, in that it is capable of having human discussions. It really does appear to be able to reason, and that reasoning wasn't programmed or designed, but emergent from its training. The one thing it doesn't do is learn in real time. Sure you can have a conversation context, but this isn't the same as being able to change the model in real time. It doesn't have an internal dialogue. Or complex motivations. But this isn't saying it isn't intelligent, only that it isn't like us. Learning in real time though I think is part of true AGI. There are some reasons to believe real time feedback from its own actions is critical to effective efficient learning.

author: @bryandraughn9830

comment:
this will be a 'before' and 'after' comment: 
Before: as a lifelong skeptic of NNs who has been punched in the face across the Go board, and is still mystified as to what the hell is going on in the mind of a NN (apart from hyperplane separation, which does make sense), i look forward to hopefully becoming a touch enlightened by the horse's mouth, because as of right now, in the 'before' phase, i am still on Chomsky's side of being dubious that DCNNs have anything to do with AGI, but i accept they are miles better than me at pattern recognition in certain tight, finite domains where they can follow a tensor path all the way to a certain conclusion (and i know i can't read ahead anywhere near that long).  And CHAT-GPT is very intriguing, even if, after having chatted to it for a few minutes, i wouldn't trust it to make me a cup of tea.  So on with the show...

After: oh dear, only 1 minute in and this guy in a designer flackjacket and cracked voice "i know it all" smartest guy in the room attitude already turns me off bigtime.  are there any real scientists working on this stuff i can listen to?
13:21 huh :(  Already into handwaving,,, this fellow is a salesman, not a researcher.  pity.
20:31 Lex should ask CHATGPT if Jordan Peterson is worth listening to, and if it said it would rather talk to a cabbage, then it could be said to have some reasoning ability

comment: Wrong way to look at it. Learning how to code teaches you the building blocks on how to create the machine to do something. This abstract creative skill of converting an idea into an automated action is not possesed by most (yet). Obviously now that AI is starting to pop off humans will slowly adopt this skill to transform the best input towards the best output. Coders still have a massive headstart on this building apps on top of openAI API and finetuning / embedding your own text within the model through the API. Prompting is kinda like building a complex function, be creative and use it as an amplifier

comment: As someone working in the field who is equally intrigued, I agree with you on most of the above. He is without a doubt a salesman and there are some telltale signs of deception and "fluff" in his speech, mannerisms and answers. Personally I'm going to be listening to the episode with Ilya Sustkever next, as he seems to be one of the "brains" behind OpenAI.
author: @FaridTaba

comment:
@FaridTaba  saw it the other day, but already can't remember what he said!  except that it's also non-technical and handwavey, but then it would be, as it's a pop art podcast for a general audience with one hand on their bag of chips and the other down their trousers, as Ardal O"Hanlon puts it :).  i can see clear flaws in CHAT GPT's nearly impressive pseudo-performance, but i still can't figure out how the designers came up with transformers, or understand how/why they work.

there's definitely something to this NN stuff, but it's clearly nothing to do with reasoning, or modelling the world to figure out what to do (except for things like Go that it can simulate to the end of a 300-move game to obtain a value estimate, which by itself is impressive enough).  High-powered statistical pattern-matching, i call it.  Chomsky calls it a steamroller! :)

comment: Great conversation, but i think there could have been more discussion on how openAI decides what does and does not get published about their models.
